# Cambridge International AS & A Level

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/63  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 339, 317]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[777, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 212, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 729, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
At a certain shop, customers arrive independently and randomly at a constant average rate of 23.4 per hour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 144, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 116, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that, in a randomly chosen 1-minute period, at least 2 customers arrive. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 181, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 365, 920, 401]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) denotes the number of customers who arrive in a randomly chosen 1-hour period.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 181, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 412, 920, 433]]<|/det|>
State a suitable approximating distribution for \(X,\) giving the value(s) of any parameter(s). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 535, 180, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 535, 680, 554]]<|/det|>
Use your approximating distribution to find \(\mathrm{P}(20< X< 30).\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 536, 917, 555]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
The lengths of pencils made at a factory are normally distributed. The standard deviation of the lengths is \(\sigma \mathrm{cm}\), and the mean is supposed to be \(10\mathrm{cm}\). An inspector thinks that the mean is actually greater than \(10\mathrm{cm}\). He takes a random sample of 50 pencils produced at the factory and finds that the mean of these 50 lengths is \(10.03\mathrm{cm}\). He then carries out a hypothesis test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 777, 168]]<|/det|>
He finds that the value of the test statistic \(z\) is 1.995 correct to 3 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 181, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 180, 390, 199]]<|/det|>
Calculate the value of \(\sigma\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 490, 180, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 490, 658, 509]]<|/det|>
Carry out the hypothesis test at the \(2.5\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 509]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 798, 176, 817]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 798, 918, 817]]<|/det|>
Explain whether it was necessary to use the Central Limit Theorem in carrying out the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 798, 920, 817]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 110]]<|/det|>
A machine dispenses coffee into cups. The volume, \(V \text{cm}^3\), of coffee in a cup was measured for a random sample of 150 cups. The results were summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[348, 120, 653, 140]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma \nu = 46 350 \qquad \Sigma \nu^2 = 14 410 800\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 144, 172]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 153, 180, 171]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 152, 860, 171]]<|/det|>
Calculate unbiased estimates of the population mean, \(\mu\), and population variance, \(\sigma^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 152, 920, 171]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 183, 917, 201]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 217, 917, 235]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 250, 917, 268]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 285, 917, 301]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 317, 917, 335]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 401, 180, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 401, 529, 419]]<|/det|>
Calculate a \(95\%\) confidence interval for \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 400, 917, 419]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 648, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
Another random sample of \(n\) cups of coffee is taken, where \(100 < n < 120\). A \(95\%\) confidence interval for \(\mu\) is calculated using this sample. You may assume that, for large samples, unbiased estimates of \(\sigma^2\) are very similar.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 710, 146, 728]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 710, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
Without calculation, state whether this confidence interval would be wider or narrower than the confidence interval found in part **(a)(ii)**. Give a reason for your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 727, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
In Urberia, the masses, in kilograms, of men have the distribution N(70.3, \(5.9^{2}\)). A certain footbridge in Urberia can take a maximum safe load of 1500 kg. When \(n\) men stand on the bridge, the probability that the bridge is unsafe is less than 0.01.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 136, 603, 156]]<|/det|>
Stating a necessary assumption, find the maximum value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 71, 606, 89]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(X\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 103, 620, 145]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}ax & 0\leqslant x\leqslant b,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 341, 166]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 178, 146, 197]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 176, 304, 200]]<|/det|>
Show that \(a = \frac{2}{b^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 460, 143, 478]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 390, 478]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{P}(X < \mathrm{E}(X)) = \frac{4}{9}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 459, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
In the past, one quarter of job applicants at a certain firm had first-class degrees. A change is made in the job description and a director of the firm believes that, on average, the proportion of job applicants with first class degrees has decreased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
In the month following the change, there were 35 job applicants, and \(r\) of these had first-class degrees. The firm carried out a hypothesis test at the \(4\%\) significance level to test the director's belief.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 144, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
Use a binomial distribution to find the largest value of \(r\) that would provide sufficient evidence that the director's belief is correct.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 198, 918, 215]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In another month, the director carries out a similar test at the \(4\%\) significance level using the 35 job applicants from that month.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 146, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
Explain the meaning of a Type I error in this context, and state the probability of a Type I error. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 408, 176, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 408, 920, 447]]<|/det|>
Given that the proportion of job applicants with first class degrees this year is actually 0.05, find the probability of a Type II error. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
